content:
This is a nice clash, but everyone in my clash got 85% or less, including me.

Validator 2 was the problem for me. It is the only test/validator that tests for the issue where the index of the code the user input doesn't match their unit number, because an earlier unit uses the same code. It's a silly bug, but it would be good to cover it in a test case, so that it doesn't take clashers by surprise. I got 100% on tests so thought I was fine, but didn't think about this issue.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good explanation and interesting idea

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this question because it can be solvable good fit for codinggame

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I believe that it is an original idea , while at the same time is  easy to solve and quite enjoyable
I tested the game in the IDE, it worked well and I enjoyed solving it.

The idea is fine, but it took me too much time to read and understand the task for a CoC.  Suggestions to improve are:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
When I read the example, I thought you wanted me to multiply 5 X 1234. 
I believe the asterisk is a constant and should be indicated as such like {{*}}
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The missing periods makes this harder to read
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
re:
" a N=10 building"
This is not the standard way of introducing a variable.

Why not say:
Write a script for an intercom in a building that has [[N]] flats.
Proper user input is the Flat Number + {{*}} + the 4 digit code.
Given the input, you should output Open, Wrong Code, or Invalid Flat .
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Your example does not need to be so long.  Do an example, where there are maybe 5 flats instead
solved this one, I thinking its a quite nice one for beginner
I like this! I think it is a fair challenge for beginners - meaning not too easy but not too difficult! Nice job!

I really like the idea of the challenge.
I think it is  easy to understand the task.
The only thing i would consider changing is the output "Wrong Flat", because for me it sounds like the input was valid but it was the wrong flat. Maybe you could change it to something like "Invalid Flat".

I tested the game in the IDE, it worked well and I enjoyed solving it.
The game is original and simple, the instructiont is clear.
Well done !

I found that interesting, too, but I would suggest moving everything that is required to know in order to write a working code just before the example.

I mean, the whole explanation about when to output 'Open', 'Wrong Code', and 'Wrong Flat' should be described just at the top, before providing the example.
The information that it's "depending on whether the provided door code and flat number were correct" isn't enough, I think.

You've forgotten some dots at the ends of the sentences, as well.

Interesting idea!

The goal is clear, with a bit of reshuffling of where things belong to and a bit of editing.

Goal section
* Suggest to change the possible answers from <<bold>> to {{constant}} format.
* "newly build" should be "newly built".

Input section
* "it's guaranteed that the input consists only of numbers and one asterisk" should be removed here. Instead, the Constraints section will state:
[[S]] is always in the format of flat number + "*" + door code.
* Delete "Valid" as in "Valid door codes" because it is kind of invalid if the code is actually not matching.

Output section
* I would suggest to move all the explanation to the Goal section, so that this section will state:
<<Line 1:>> A string {{Open}}, {{Wrong Code}} or {{Wrong Flat}}

Wording
* For the sake of consistency, especially given that one of the possible answer is "Wrong Flat", suggest these wordings to replace the original ones:
Goal: "newly built building", "flat number"
Input: "flat number"
Output: "flat number"
instead of a mix of "building"/"apartment"/"flat(s)".

Test cases
* I would suggest more variation of length of door codes in the inputs, if possible.
* The last pair of test/validator is inconsistent with the constraint that N should be at least 1.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement.

Thanks.
A marvelouse clash I ' d enjoy doing something like that in global. Clear task and original idea.
Any feedback is appreciated, please also tell me if the goal is clear enough and you're able to understand it quickly
glad you enjoyed :)
Thank you so much for these suggestions, I've corrected the descriptions and the last testcase (great eye, I didn't see the last case not matching constraints), thank you :)
thanks for the suggestions! tbh I'd leave it after the example. It may be a bit confusing being above everything
Hey. sorry for begging, but I've just published it. Can you approve?

Thank you :D A few more follow-up comments:

Goal section
* "apartment number" will be revised to "flat number".
* "flat building" can be simplified as "building".
* "its flat" will be revised to "his flat".

Input section
* "apartment number" will be revised to "flat number".
* About my earlier comment on deleting "Valid", I don't know what I was thinking at that time, but the word "Valid" should be kept! I am very sorry about that.

Output section
* You can now remove the 2nd to 4th lines.

Test cases
* When I suggested more variation of length of door codes in the inputs, if possible, I meant like one test may include door codes of length 3, and another may include door codes of length 7. That was because I saw that originally the lengths were either 4 or 5 and there was not much variety.
I did not mean to include codes of different lengths in a SINGLE case, because I think it is rare for the codes to be of different lengths for the same building.

Thanks.

Thank you again!! You really spend a lot of time making the codingame a better place. So I've fixed these things, I think the variety in lengths is now enough and they're the same length now. I guess there are no more english pronouncation/words issues (to be fair as a non-native I've never used the words apartment,flat for anything so they got me confused)... I also thought about adding Reverse mode, maybe it wouldn't be that hard as the outputs speak for themselves, but I don't know if non-mathematic based questions should land on reverse as well
edit:also they take a bit long to submit so if you've entered the page right now you may see the older version
